thread.title: The things we should be talking about when we're talking about Brexit

author: Graeme Whitfield
title: The things we should be talking about when we're talking about Brexit
text:
Business opinion The things we should be talking about when we're talking about Brexit Journal business editor Graeme Whitfield on the many things that have slipped off the agenda as everyone obsesses about Brexit Share Business opinion Anti-Brexit Remain campaigners (L) heatedly debate with Pro-Brexit Leave campaigners outside the Houses of Parliament (Image: Getty Images) Get business updates directly to your inbox Subscribe Thank you for subscribing We have more newsletters Show me See our privacy notice Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email
Here is a list of the things we’re not talking enough about:
Child poverty, the need to improve skills throughout the generations, the horror show that is Universal Credit, climate change, school budgets, the gender pay gap, the rising use of food banks, the threats and opportunities of automation, how to best manage mass migration, the challenges of multiculturalism, the benefits of multiculturalism, library closures, the narrowing of school curriculums, the pros and cons of social media, inequality between (and within) regions, how to build more homes, bringing together health and social services, knife crime, overuse of antibiotics, childhood obesity, fully dualling the A1, our complicity in what is happening in Yemen, the importance (and limits) of free speech, productivity, anti Semitism on the left, Islamaphobia on the right, homelessness, funding the NHS, reforming the NHS, police numbers, combating drugs, legalising drugs, driving a green transport revolution, driving a green energy revolution, Trump, people who vote for Trump, when the new Bruce Springsteen album will come out, the ageing workforce, tensions between the generations, inequality, stem cell research, regenerating former industrial areas, the brain drain to London, regional imbalances in infrastructure spending, the difficulty for young people getting on the housing ladder, lack of spending on mental health, prison reform, the slowdown of social mobility, public services that are better delivered by the private sector, public services that shouldn’t be delivered by the private sector, austerity, the underfunding of further education, levels of student debt, funding higher education, how and why Chris Grayling is still a Cabinet Minister, when is executive pay too high, the underrepresentation of women in politics and business, the future of the High Street, reforming business rates, tax avoidance by multinational corporations, the closure of pubs, the closure of banks, the closure of post offices and the ridiculous inflation in the price of Freddos.
